title: SB 1.17.43-45 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 24-03-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiran Dhasya Gyanan Janishalakaya Chakshurun Meelitam Yena Tasvain Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The session begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras.

segments.key_quote: The most fortunate emperor Maharaj Pariksit, who was entrusted with the kingdom of Hastinapura by Maharaj Yudhishthira when Maharaj Yudhishthira desired to retire to the forest is now ruling the world with great success due to his being glorified by the deeds of the kings of the Kuru dynasty.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verses to be discussed (SB 1.17.43-44) and reads the translation, focusing on Maharaj Pariksit's successful rule.

segments.key_quote: The prolonged sacrificial ceremonies undertaken by the sages of Naimisharanya were begun shortly after the demise of Maharaj Pariksit.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the context of the verses, discussing the sacrifice at Naimisharanya, the role of Suta Goswami, and the timing of the events in relation to Maharaj Pariksit's reign.

segments.key_quote: So, he was reciting the Puranas when Lord Balaram visited the place, and Romaharshana Suta did not show proper respect to Balaram.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Romaharshana Suta's disrespect towards Lord Balaram and the subsequent punishment.

segments.key_quote: But he thought himself superior to Lord Balaram, because he was a Brahmana, he was a learned Personality.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Romaharshana Suta's pride and his mistaken belief in his superiority over Lord Balaram due to his brahminical status.

segments.key_quote: And Balaram actually purified him Balaram delivered him of his sinful tendency of his sinful behavior and then Roma Arjuna Sutta's son Ugrasava Sutta was actually instructed by Balaram to take over the father's position in order to continue the sacrifice
segments.summary: The speaker explains how Balaram purified Romaharshana Suta and instructed his son, Ugrashrava Suta, to continue the sacrifice, then addresses the question of why the present tense is used in the verse.

segments.key_quote: Another reason why present tense is used is the principles of Maharaj Pariksit can still be continued and human society can still be improved if there is determination by the authorities.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to explain the use of the present tense, connecting it to the enduring principles of Maharaj Pariksit's administration and his efforts to control Kali.

segments.key_quote: Modern administrators want to banish corruption from the state, but fools are the ones who want to banish corruption from the state, but fools are the ones who want to banish corruption from the state, but fools as they are, they do not know how to do it.
segments.summary: The speaker criticizes modern administrators for their ineffective attempts to combat corruption, highlighting their contradictory policies that promote sinful activities.

segments.key_quote: Prabhupada says you cannot drive out corruption simply by some vigilance department or some anti-corruption ministry etc. By legislation you cannot drive out alone.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that corruption cannot be eradicated through legislation alone, but requires a society based on the principles of Dharma: austerity, cleanliness, mercy, and truthfulness.

segments.key_quote: Maharaj Pariksit, the son of Abhimanyu, is so experienced that by dint of his expert administration, he has been able to do so many things. He has been able to do so many things. He has been able to do so many things. He has been able to do so many things. He has been able to do so many things. and patronage, it has been possible for you to perform a sacrifice such as this.
segments.summary: The speaker reads and explains verse 45, highlighting Maharaj Pariksit's expert administration and its role in enabling the sages to perform the sacrifice, and concludes the session.
